an4.70:1.1: “At a time when kings are unprincipled, royal officials become unprincipled.
an4.70:1.2: When royal officials are unprincipled, brahmins and householders become unprincipled.
an4.70:1.3: When brahmins and householders are unprincipled, the people of town and country become unprincipled.
an4.70:1.4: When the people of town and country are unprincipled, the courses of the moon and sun become erratic.
an4.70:1.5: … the courses of the stars and constellations …
an4.70:1.8: the seasons and years become erratic.
an4.70:1.9: … the blowing of the winds becomes erratic and chaotic.
an4.70:1.11: … the heavens don’t provide enough rain.
an4.70:1.13: When people eat crops that have ripened erratically, they become short-lived, ugly, weak, and sickly.
an4.70:2.1: At a time when kings are principled, royal officials become principled.
an4.70:2.3: people of town and country become principled.
an4.70:2.4: When the people of town and country are principled, the courses of the sun and moon become regular.
an4.70:2.8: the seasons and years become regular.
an4.70:2.9: … the blowing of the winds becomes regular and orderly.
an4.70:2.11: … the heavens provide plenty of rain.
an4.70:2.12: When the heavens provide plenty of rain, the crops ripen well.
an4.70:2.13: When people eat crops that have ripened well, they become long-lived, beautiful, strong, and healthy.

an4.70:3.4: because their leader is off course.
an4.70:4.4: what do you expect the rest to do?
